entry.title: Combined summary - Ark: An Alternative Privacy-preserving Second Layer Solution
entry.summary: The email conversation revolves around the implementation and mechanics of the Ark protocol as an alternative to the Lightning network. Ark enables users to send and receive funds without liquidity constraints, using virtual UTXOs (vTXOs) that exist off-chain and must be spent within four weeks. This approach consumes less on-chain footprint compared to Lightning and does not require opening and closing channels.To enhance anonymity, vTXO values are limited to a specific range of sats. Users can acquire vTXOs from others or transfer their on-chain UTXOs to virtual UTXOs through a process called lifting. The Ark Service Provider (ASP) acts as an untrusted intermediary, facilitating anonymous off-chain payments and providing liquidity to the network.The conversation also discusses the potential vulnerabilities in the system, including double-spending and collusion between the sender and receiver. Suggestions are made to address these concerns, such as adding an additional round of interactivity between the sender and the ASP, disclosing a revocation secret for refund transactions without compromising transaction broadcast or user funds.One topic of discussion is the capital requirements and costs associated with using Bitcoin as a base layer for internal transfers. It is mentioned that Alice, who has one million customers, would need to hold several billion dollars worth of BTC in a hot wallet to serve all her customers. The per-user cost in fees and capital service is estimated at around $1,000 per year.The email thread also explores the use of a watchtower program for secure coin refreshing, which runs on an internet-connected server and helps users refresh their coins periodically. This program ensures the protection of user funds during reorganizations and prevents unauthorized access to wallet passwords.Furthermore, the conversation delves into the claim about pool transactions on the Ark platform and their potential vulnerability to double-spending by Ark service providers. The impact on recipients who pay lightning invoices with incoming zero-conf vTXOs is discussed, considering that ASPs on Ark serve as liquidity providers, blinded coinjoin coordinators, and Lightning service providers.In summary, the email conversation covers various aspects of the Ark protocol, including its mechanics, vulnerabilities, capital requirements, and the implementation of a watchtower program for secure coin refreshing. It also addresses the potential risks associated with pool transactions and their impact on recipients using zero-conf vTXOs for lightning payments.
